snippet: The practice of exchanging one asset for another without incurring taxes has spread to major corporations from the family farmers the tax break was intended to help.
abstract: Some major American corporations routinely use practice of exchanging one asset for another without incurring taxes, policy originally put into place 90 years ago to help family farmers claim lucrative tax savings; method by which corporations have expanded this tax break, which is costing United States government billions of dollars, illustrates how special interests have learned to use the tax code to maximum effect.
lead_paragraph: The practice of exchanging one asset for another without incurring taxes has spread to major corporations from the family farmers the tax break was intended to help.

headline.seo: Companies Exploit Tax Break for Asset Exchanges, Trial Evidence Shows
headline.main: Major Companies Push the Limits of a Tax Break
